results.title: Christian Boltanski
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
A comprehensive documentary on one of the most important contemporary artists of 20th Century France, Christian Boltanski. Interviewed by Melvyn Bragg, Boltanski’s childhood influences, mostly the affects of the Holocaust on society in post-war France are explored in direct reference to a series of Boltanski’s work spanning over a period of 30 years. Boltanski’s passion for ethnology, collections and death, as themes central to his art, are discussed in relationship to his work. The subtlety of broad themes are constantly explored in his work: the nature of the killer, heroes and villains, quantifying loss. Boltanski uses mostly photographs in his installation pieces. Works featured in the documentary: ‘Shadows’ (1985); ‘Sans Souci’ (1991); ‘The Reserves’ (1993); ‘The Dead Swiss’; ‘The Art of the Venice Biennale 1938’ (1993); ‘Comical Skits’(1974).

results.title: W. Eugene Smith
results.creator_credit: Gene Lasko, Kirk Morris, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.), WQED and WES Foree
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Renowned war photographer W. Eugene Smith (1918-78) photographed the victims of war throughout his distinguished career. This is an insightful portrait of a powerful and sensitive artist who used his photographs to transmit a message against the greed, the stupidity and the intolerance that causes wars that bring cruelty and suffering to humanity.

results.title: Isamu Noguchi
results.creator_credit: Bruce W. Bassett and Whitgate Productions Ltd
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Isamu Noguchi (1904-88) was one of the world’s leading sculptors of the 20th century. By rights American, residing in both Long Island and the Japanese island Shikoku, Noguchi throughout the documentary makes reference to his ‘nomadic’ life influenced by his family upbringing and this relationship to his work. Throughout the documentary, Noguchi explores his relationship with place, sculpture and stone (his chosen material) discussing freely his ideas and motivations. Some of his large scale commissions from the 60’s to the late 70’s are featured in locations as varied as Paris, Detroit, Japan and Mexico City along with the sets he designed for Martha Graham’s dance “Cortege of Eagles” (see 16mm film title #015721 of the same title). Written, directed and narrated by Bruce W. Bassett, this documentary features some iconic photography by Bruce G. Sparks that captures the spirit of the time reflecting the value of Noguchi’s legacy.

results.title: The Story of fashion. Vol. 1: Remembrance of things past
results.creator_credit: Roberta Guerra, Eila Hershon and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
In the first episode of this three part series, Karl Lagerfeld discusses the history of fashion from its rise in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries to the present day. Lagerfeld’s commentary, layered over a backdrop of fashion illustrations and archival footage, provides a broad survey of the evolution of this fascinating industry. The film begins by introducing the work of Charles Worth, inventor of haute couture and explores the changes of fashion over time to the work of some of the leading designers of today: Donna Karan; Fendi; Versace; Ralph Lauren; Valentino. Other areas that are discussed through interviews with leading industry players include dressmaking, fur, embroidery, hats, hairstyles, magazines and advertising techniques. Commentary written by Meredith Etherington-Smith and spoken by Diana Quick.

results.title: Andy Warhol
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Andy Warhol was born Andrew Warhola in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, 1928. Upon graduation from Carnegie Institute of Technology, he moved to New York and began working as a commercial artist where his success in graphic arts and illustration was celebrated. This documentary begins with his early commercial work and follows his career over 20 years until his death in 1987. Contains interviews with cast members from Warhol’s films “Sleep” and “Chelsea Girls”.

results.title: Jasper John: ideas in paint
results.creator_credit: Rick Tejada-Flores and WHYY Inc Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Narrated by Polly Adams, this interesting documentary explores the paintings of Jasper Johns and follows his career from the 1950’s through to 1988. As one of the major forces on the American art scene, Johns rejected abstraction in favour of realism and layed the ground work for Pop Art and Minimalism. Featuring excerpts from interviews with Richard Serra, Hilton Kramer, Merce Cunningham, Frank Stella, John Cage and many other friends including his agent Leo Castelli, this documentary provides a broad overview of his career. The soundtrack includes readings from composer John Cage.

results.title: Robert Motherwell and the New York school
results.creator_credit: Catherine Tatge, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.), Thirteen and International Cultural Programming
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Robert Motherwell was the leading figure in the Abstract Expressionist movement in New York in the 1940’s and was to revolutionise the face of American painting. Made shortly before his death in 1991 this is director Tatge’s elegy to Motherwell, the vanguard of American modernism. Along with Arshille Gorky, William Bazeodis, Hans Hoffman, Franz Kline, William de Kooning, Barnett Newman, Jackson Pollock, Mark Rothko and David Smith, Motherwell made up what is known as “The New York school”. The journey or search in their work as artists was to make art in the U.S. that was equal to that in Europe. Within a hostile political environment and known historically as the most hated of all the art movements, the Abstract Expressionists had achieved this by the early 1950’s. With archival footage and interviews this documentary paints an inspirational portrait of a man and movement in one of the most volatile times in modern history. Juxtaposed throughout is footage of Motherwell preparing for his retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum in New York.

results.title: Marcel Duchamp: a game of chess
results.creator_credit: Jean-Marie Drot, RM Associates and INA France
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Filmed in 1963 the program offers an in-depth dialogue between renowned artist Marcel Duchamp and film-maker Jean-Marie Drot over a game of chess and a tour of Duchamp’s first one man show at the Pasadena Art Museum in 1963. Duchamp details his life and work only 5 years before his death in a discussion of his time in the United States after fleeing France in 1915. The discussion touches on his view of the country in social and political terms as well as its impact on his own work, intermingled with visual contemplations on the progression of his artwork from painting to photographs throughout his career. Recognised for varying artistic practices which included brushes with Impressionism and Cubism, Duchamp is also largely known for his founding influence in Surrealism and Dada. Here he recounts the stages of his work with full colour shots of the relevant pieces evoking a detailed sense of the significance of these different times in his life personally, politically and most of all artistically. The game of chess which punctuates the dialogue, a passion for Duchamp throughout his career, acts as an insightful metaphor for the mental discipline he applies to his work and an avenue for its explanation and contemplation. Contains some scenes in b&w. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Francis Bacon
results.creator_credit: David Hinton, RM Arts and London Weekend Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
This seminal documentary, edited and narrated by Melvyn Bragg remains one of the ‘stand out’ documentaries that surveys the life, work and motivations of British painter, Francis Bacon, through a series of interviews. Bacon, an extraordinary man, laconically introduces the relationship between broad formalist concerns and attempts to connect with the subconscious. Bacon articulates his response to images of a distressed humanity, revealing his deep fascination with the human body and its connection with much of Bacon’s life philosophies. Gritty in content, Bacon’s paintings reveal much of the ‘violence of life and death’ but seek to describe the normality of this with controlled sense of chaos, ‘capturing the moment’.

results.title: Vermeer: light, love and silence
results.creator_credit: Michael Gill, RM Arts and Malone Gill Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Written, produced, directed by Michael Gill and presented by Melvyn Bragg “Light, love and silence” focuses on the artist Jan Vermeer’s painting style and his intimate depictions of domestic interiors. Little known outside Holland for almost 200 years after his death, he is now considered one of the greatest painters of the seventeenth century. This documentary examines his paintings through detailed descriptions and discusses his technical skill, use of perspective and extraordinary understanding of light guided by the use of a camera obscura. Although very little is known about this intriguing artist for he left no letters, drawings or clues relating to the intention of his paintings, interviews with academics including Dr Jonathon Miller and Svetlana Alpers provide a greater insight into the social, political and scientific environment in which he worked.
